message.content:
A metonymy is a figure of speech that refers to something by the name of something else that is closely associated with it, or by which it can be identified. For example, "the White House" can refer to the president of the United States because they both are located in Washington D.C., the capital city of the United States.

In this sense, a metonymy is a type of synecdoche that uses a part of something to represent the whole or vice versa. It is also known as a "transference" or a "metaphorical association."
